title: Monday, 20th March, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM11:01am

Hi there

PM11:02am

Well, actually it's just a bit stale

How about Fox & Freaks?

PM11:03am

BE11:08am

E8-10bn value unlock

11:08 am
BE11:08am

Or ringfencing the worst bit of the business, you prefer.

PM11:08am

Certainly the most problematic

PM11:09am

· Vodafone India will be deconsolidated by Vodafone on announcement and reported as a joint venture post-closing, reducing Vodafone Group net debt by approximately INR552 billion (US$8.2 billion) and lowering Vodafone Group leverage by around 0.3x Net Debt/EBITDA[4]. The transaction is expected to be accretive to Vodafone's cash flow[5] from the first full year post-completion.

11:09 am
BE11:10am

Here's Caz to take us through the main points, and save us the bother of reading the statements.

BE11:10am

(1) The agreed merger ratio values Vodafone India at 6.4x EV/EBITDA and Idea wireless at 6.3x EV/EBITDA. Idea’s 11.2% stake in Indus has been contributed at $1.0bn, (2) The deal will see Vodafone start with 50% equity ownership, but sell down a 4.9% stake immediately to Aditya Birla for $579m in cash (Rs108/Idea share). As such Vodafone will deconsolidate India with immediate effect enabling the parent to guide ex India for Mar-18, (3) Vodafone will transfer $8.2bn of debt to India reducing group leverage by 0.3x, (4) Aditya Birla has the right to acquire a further 9.5% stake from Vodafone, over the coming 3 years, for Rs130/Idea share ($1.3bn of proceeds) thus equalizing their equity ownership. If this does not occur Vodafone will subsequently sell shares in the open market, (5) Targeted synergies are worth an estimated INR670bn ($10bn) post integration costs and a $0.5bn liberalization payment (JPMe $9bn). Run-rate synergies are expected at $2.1bn pa by year 4 of which 60% opex, (6) The deal is expected to complete in 2018 and be FCF accretive for Vodafone from year one. The Indian entity will start at 4.4x net debt to EBITDA, but post a sale of towers and post synergies will see this fall to 3.0x. The mid-term dividend policy will see excess cash flow distributed to shareholders, (7) Post deal, Vodafone will evaluate (partial or full) exit options for its 42% stake in Indus towers. We value this stake at €3.9bn.

BE11:11am

But does this fix Vodafone? Of course it doesn't.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

It takes €7.5bn debt off Vodafone's balance sheet

PM11:12am

And ring-fences a problem asset. This has tangible value, surely

BE11:13am

Yep. It's capitulation in the face of a price war, really.

11:13 am
PM11:13am

True

BE11:13am

Remember when Vodafone was India's growth market?

PM11:13am

hmm

11:13 am

It was quite recently. Loads of presentations about how Indians have six sims per person, etc.

BE11:14am

Thing is, there's no pricing power in mobile. Which is weird.

BE11:15am

I guess it moves management onto the next problem markets on the list -- as in, the UK and Ireland.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

But we've probably discussed that theme enough.

PM11:15am

Notice that the Deutsche team had lunch with the Voda CTO recently

PM11:15am

Johan Wibergh

11:15 am
PM11:16am

I have their notes...

PM11:16am

Lunch with Group CTO Johan Wibergh
Whilst not encouraging us to believe that some 5G growth nirvana is on the near-term horizon, we drew comfort from Johan Wibergh’s views on future network efficiency, his thoughts on fibre dogma, and his conviction on the benefits of Cloudification. It appears that unit capital deflation continues apace to support high mobile traffic growth. Reassuringly, 5G can be deployed on the 3G grid without material densification. Fibre isn’t a sine qua non either. Now if only Johan’s colleagues can slow the rate of decline in per gigabyte yield.......

PM11:16am

Lots here on 5G

11:16 am
PM11:16am

I don't know

PM11:16am

Does anyone else notice that 4G is worse than 3G in London?

BE11:17am

I don't find that.

11:17 am
PM11:17am

Here's the notes of Robert Grindle and team in any case

PM11:17am

Enthusiastic (but not dogmatic) on Cloud
Vodafone’s Cloud deployment (45% network functions to be virtualised by 2020) drives 40% savings on infrastructure costs (hardware, storage and maintenance) whilst improving business agility allowing targeted increases in capacity, in line with real rather than expected demand (e.g. 10 min vs 6 month provisioning). The decoupling of hardware and software helps Vodafone’s purchasing power. At present, it is easier to change h/w than s/w supplier as h/w is more standardized (more generic s/w will be available with Cloud). Cloud shouldn’t become a dogma, however, and Vodafone is selective.
5G overhyped....
Wibergh views that the capabilities and timing of 5G are over-hyped as some champions justify ownership of higher-band spectrum, incumbents look for virtue in fibre capillarity and equipment suppliers burnish expectations for the next industry growth driver. Mobile tech. gens. span a decade and not all the promises of next gen. will be available on day 1. Wibergh is sceptical on the business model for fixed mmWave access due to propagation issues.

PM11:17am

....but can be realised on existing infrastructure
Contrary to prevailing orthodoxy, Wibergh pushed back on the idea that 5G at higher frequencies needs substantial cell densification. The beam-forming functionality from massive MIMO would allow 3.5GHz spectrum (for example) to be used over the existing 1800/2100MHz grid, allowing a substantial increase in traffic capacity at modest extra cost. He is happy with current network quality/performance and the sustainability of unit capital deflation.
Not all backhaul needs to be fibre
Vodafone is investing in fibre backhaul (95% of large city sites by 2020) which is cost-effective over time, however regular use case 5G with latency limits of 8-10ms can work perfectly well even with 2-hop microwave (1ms additional delay). VOD could consider additional fibre deployment, e.g success based to follow profitable growth or if regulatory change creates an opportunity (not currently seen). Vodafone will also benefit from dark fibre access as it becomes available, but views that the business case for duct and pole access (DPA) is tougher at this time.

BE11:25am

As we discussed in our outlook note Not out of the woods yet(12 Dec 2016), we are
cautious on the European insurance sector as we see limited scope for earnings and
dividend growth. We believe the FY16 results bear this thesis out, with no underlying
earnings growth and limited increase in payouts. Although the sector has been lifted
by rising interest rates, this was insufficient to reverse pressure on investment results.
The sector's dividend yield remains attractive, but with limited growth, will its relative
attractiveness fade? Lack of earnings growth, healthy balance sheets and low funding
costs are in the meantime paving the way for the next big theme for the sector, M&A.
Balance sheets are also increasingly key – stocks such as Allianz and Aviva got
rewarded for capital strength and capital repatriation.

BE11:25am

Operating trends – growth remains lacklustre: EPS growth in FY16 was marginally
negative at -2% for the sector and dividend growth very limited at +2%, driven by specific
companies that haven’t entirely used the payout ratio lever yet. Consensus EPS revisions
are broadly flat for the sector, confirming our view that EPS beats have been relatively low
quality and largely driven by realised gains, reserve releases and abnormally benign claims
environment – which consensus cannot extrapolate into the future.
Not all Solvency ratios are equal, beware of tiering: Quality of capital matters arguably
even more than the ratio. In this note we present a comparison of capital structures, and
focus on Price to Unrestricted Tier 1 capital vs Returns on Unrestricted Tier 1 as a
potential valuation tool for the sector. Dutch insurers stand out with a relatively low
component of Tier 1 capital, which can create eligibility issues and heightened volatility.

11:25 am
PM11:25am

(Mouselet - i stand corrected!)

BE11:25am

key stocks we would highlight include:
 Prudential (OW, PT 1921p) – Pru remains our Top Pick in the sector as it offers one
scarce resource – growth. Its Asia business remains a jewel in the crown, with a
seventh consecutive year of double-digit earnings, cash and new business growth.
Regulatory headwinds in the US are reversing, the asset management businesses are
at inflection points, and the company may take corporate action at its UK operations.

Prudential PLC (PRU:LSE): Last: 1,759, down 1.5 (-0.09%), High: 1,764, Low: 1,752, Volume: 989.99k

BE11:27am

We believe UK motor pricing has
inflected and Admiral should benefit from the pricing tailwind, although this could be offset by declining reserve releases. Special dividends of c£150m expected over three years makes it one of the highest dividend yielding names. Our rating is based on valuation, and we see more upside in other names in the sector

A spokesperson for Uber would not comment on the suggestion. However, shortly after this story was published, another source, who also did not want to be named, said there was "zero chance" of Mr Kalanick stepping down when the new COO is announced.

11:31 am
PM11:31am

Theresa May is to trigger the two-year Article 50 EU exit process on March 29.

Sir Tim Barrow, Britain's EU ambassador, informed the office of Donald Tusk, EU Council president, on Monday morning that the formal letter would be submitted next Wednesday.

Downing St declined to say whether the letter would contain detailed negotiating objectives. Mrs May will make a Cimmons statement on the same day.

Mr Tusk is expected to respond formally within 48 hours but a detailed EU negotiating position is not expected to emerge until later in the spring.

The pre-announcement of the timing of the Article 50 letter is partly aimed at preparing markets for the formal start of Brexit.

Downing St has been anxious in recent months to counter the risk that major Brexit announcements are inevitably accompanied by falls in sterling.

11:33 am
PM11:34am

Actually, was just reading some Malcolm Barr earlier

PM11:34am

JPM

PM11:34am

Discussing this story in Politico

11:34 am
PM11:34am

http://www.politic...trade-deal-brexit/

PM11:34am

Britain’s Brexit Plan B

PM11:34am

Here's Barr

11:34 am
PM11:35am

This cites “Geneva based officials” as stating that UK officials are ‘investigating the possibility of keeping tariffs between Britain and the EU at zero as part of an interim arrangement that could last up to 10 years”. The story highlights Article 24 of the GATT as providing a basis for such an interim arrangement. Beyond these sources around the WTO, the story makes references to one (unnamed) Euroskeptic MP as suggesting the WTO would tolerate such an arrangement if the UK and EU were close to agreeing a trade deal. The story notes in passing that it is “highly unlikely” the EU would agree to such a deal without “significant concessions on budget contributions and free movement”.

PM11:35am

The problem with this story is that it is looking entirely in the wrong place for a possible constraint on the ability of the EU-UK to reach a deal, and then placing too much significance on the absence of a constraint when it fails to find one.

PM11:35am

The WTO is unlikely to act as a very meaningful constraint on any kind of arrangement between the UK and EU given (a) that it is primarily about facilitating trade between countries, and (b) its dispute resolution processes are very slow moving. The fact that the WTO has a provision which could potentially allow tariff free trade between the UK and EU for a long period comes as no surprise. But the problems has never been that WTO rules would preclude a lengthy transition. The problem is with the willingness of the UK-EU to enter such an arrangement, and how such an arrangement could be made compatible with the EU rules which currently underpin trade. If there is no UK-EU agreement, it is not WTO rules which will stop UK goods at EU borders, but EU rules.

11:35 am
PM11:35am

The UK’s starting position is that a new trade agreement with the EU can be concluded within the near two years allowed by Article 50 (along with a withdrawal agreement and agreement on any transition measures required for smooth implementation of the new regime). It is absolutely vital to note the semantic distinction between “transition arrangements” as often discussed broadly, and the “transition arrangements” referred to by David Davis. For Davis, transitional arrangements are smoothing the adjustment to a set of arrangements which has already been agreed. For many others “transition arrangements” is about creating more time for negotiations to agree the end state beyond the two years afforded by Article 50. Although the politico website may have a source in Geneva who is prepared to talk about what officials from the Department of International Trade are doing in Geneva, they are not the officials who are going to be running the talks with the EU.

PM11:35am

This story is likely a foretaste of a phenomenon which we will have to get used to as the negotiations between the UK and EU begin. There will be a lot of ‘sources’ who have glimpses of insight into a small section of the discussions or the views of one of the many interested parties, and who may be prepared to talk to journalists. The newsflow around discussions with Greece provides something of a template, and demonstrates that all such stories must be read and understood in their full context.

G4S PLC (GFS:LSE): Last: 294.60, down 6.3 (-2.09%), High: 295.60, Low: 292.30, Volume: 895.32k
BE11:40am

Which is an HSBC downgrade.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

They're not sure what G4S's turnaround strategy is for.

BE11:42am

G4S is a tricky stock; it qualifies as a turnaround story. Ideally, valuation would be on the future “recovered earnings” of the busines discounted back to a present value.

However, the company moves business lines in and out of its “portfolio” and “discontinued” segments. This makes it hard to discern trends in the business and isolate what the business emergent from the “transformation strategy” will make in profits, or what multiple to apply to it.

BE11:42am

Plus, the unfortunate detail of having to pay people.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

G4S is very largely two business lines, Guarding and Cash Handling. The former is about labour utilisation, and possibly, about technology augmented labour utilisation.

As such the business must make a turn on the labour it provides. Contracts are largely bid on a man hour basis, still. Unbilled time, unplanned overtime and unscheduled absence are expensive, extremely margin dilutive. Technology can help but it remains unclear, in a world where such tech is accessible to many, how competitive advantage may be maintained. The labour used by G4S, and its competitors, is probably largely above minimum wage levels but, perhaps, not sufficiently so to avoid ‘differential maintenance’ pressures on the cost base.

Contracts will largely include labour cost pass through clauses, but there is little evidence that these have offered much protection on an industry level. At a company level, we believe, that tweaks to working practices, and perhaps a little tech, have helped but may have finite scope. We suspect there is likely to be cost pressure in coming years. The latter, cash handling business, is in valuation terms afflicted by the perception that electronic payments will erode the usage of cash. We have struggled to find compelling evidence that there is a rapid movement to less cash circulating. In fact no one knows how many times a note in circulation is used. Most countries show growth in cash withdrawals from ATMs and in those that do not there are alternative explanations.

BE11:44am

So ......

BE11:44am

Our EPS estimates are 3.7%, 3.3% and 6% below consensus largely because we see labour cost pressures as greater than implied by consensus. We continue to value the business on a multiple of 13.4x 2018e EPS, as previously, and given small upgrades to our forecast (currency largely) we derive a Target Price of 259p, from 245p previously. The complexity of numbers, and the still relatively high debt burden, make us hesitant to use a higher forward multiple.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

And that's it for sellside today.

undefined
PM11:45am

There's more on this theme of the news industry being to blame for everything

11:45 am
PM11:45am

This has just landed from Joe W

BE11:45am

Oh good.

PM11:45am

It turns out that it's all the media's fault! Well, sort of. See, ever since the election there have been a ton of stories trying to explain why volatility is so muted despite all the "uncertainty" out there in the political realm. None of the stories are all that compelling though. On Friday, my Bloomberg colleague Cameron Crise (whose work you can find on the Terminal's Markets Live blog) dove further into this seeming gap between uncertainty and volatility and come to a very interesting conclusion. It turns out that attempts to measure uncertainty include both a news component (e.g. keywords in articles) and a real-world component (e.g. expiring fiscal-policy measures). It turns out when you separate out the two components, there's a very striking divergence underway.

11:45 am
PM11:45am

Markets Live blog ?

BE11:46am

Yeah, they've been doing that since November.

PM11:46am

The news bit reflects the volume of stories screaming about all the uncertainty out there. But the real-world measures are quite tame. You can see on the attached chart the big gap that's emerged between those, and what the media is hyping up. It turns out that this is often the case. The media is very excitable, and the blue line tends to gyrate wildly while the white line (reality) doesn't swing to such extremes. This suggests that in trying to reconcile low volatility and high uncertainty, part of the answer is in just turning off the news (please don't do that though!) and in paying attention to real-world signals. You can catch Crise talking more about this, alongside Bloomberg's Dani Burger, if you go to the 38-minute mark of Friday's What'd You Miss.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

- Astra’s business is set to turn around as it enters a vital 18-month period

- Its generic headwinds should lessen through 2017 and by the end of the year all major patent expiries will have annualised

- The pipeline is already having an impact, with Tagrisso and Lynparza beating expectations from launch

- There are at least five other blockbuster launches in the near term, which should ensure a strong recovery post-2017.

- Berenberg reiterates its Buy rating, with a target price of 5670p, suggesting 17% upside. BUY.

undefined
PM12:01pm

You got us over the line Bryce

12:01 pm
PM12:01pm

I had some Andrew Garthwaite ready just in case

PM12:02pm

Might as well share -- Credit Suisse strategist of course

PM12:02pm

Equities: Climbing the wall of worry

12:02 pm
PM12:02pm

Omg smile That's the original header

BE12:02pm

(@Boncoeur: I use broker-supplied diaries generally.)

PM12:02pm

Prefer equities to bonds: Our clear-cut view is that investors should be overweight equities versus bonds and credit. We now see less chance of a second-half correction in equities and thus raise our mid-year and year-end targets to 2,400 and 2,500, from 2,350 and 2,300, respectively. We stick to our mid-year targets of 3,500 on Euro Stoxx 50 and 20,500 on Nikkei 225.

12:02 pm
PM12:03pm

The big-picture positives: (i) US wage growth has been more muted than expected, making us believe the unemployment rate consistent with full employment is probably 4.2%, not 4.8%. This is critical because cycles peak when unemployment is 50-100bps below NAIRU; (ii) for the first time in 30 years the five-year risk-adjusted return of equities is better than that for bonds and realised equity volatility is now below that of bonds; this should encourage a bond for equity switch yet equity inflows are still below 2013 peak levels; (iii) earnings revisions remain positive (we raise our US EPS growth forecast to 8.7% from 6%); (iv) we think inflation expectations will rise closer to 3% (2.2% currently) and equities do not de-rate until inflation rises above 3%; (v) above all, equities remain the least expensive major asset class: the ERP is 5.4% vs warranted of 4.1%; and (vi) excess liquidity is consistent with re-rating.

PM12:03pm

wo events that could make us turn negative: (i) if the unemployment rate falls 50-100bps below NAIRU and wage growth rises above 3%. This increasingly looks like a 2018 event; and (ii) if the 10-year UST yield rises to 3.0-3.5%. We think we are in the late stages of the bull market, so ultimately most of the rise in the next year would reverse into the next bear market.

PM12:03pm

We see few of the catalysts for a major market peak: Prior to most market peaks (c.90% of the time), credit spreads widen, for an average of 7 months (they have widened marginally in the US, but not in Europe). Otherwise, the catalysts have been one of: very clear overvaluation (average ERP at peak of 2.5%); over-investment; equities peak 4 months ahead of a recession; negative earnings revisions; high retail inflows; talk of a 'new paradigm'; and a sharp narrowing of breadth.

12:03 pm
PM12:03pm

The tactical issues that don't worry us: (i) lead indicators are peaking (but c71% of the time on a 3-month view the S&P can rise); (ii) some sentiment indicators are becoming excessive (e.g. bull-bear/insider selling, but our aggregate measure isn't); and (iii) the market has typically risen c5% in the 6 months after the third Fed rate hike.

PM12:03pm

The tactical issues to focus on: (i) corporate net buying slowing and buybacks as a style underperforming (but FCF after dividends and buybacks is still positive); (ii) speculators are very long oil while the market has been moving against them, and the oil price has had a strong correlation over the past two years with risk assets (but our house view is $62pb by year-end and the correlation between equities and oil has started to fall); and (iii) cyclicals underperforming, which leads to the S&P 500 falling c73% of the time in the next 3 months (though it has not done so in the past month).
